So Chia won't allow pumping and dumping.  

I'm more comfortable with Chia Network short term control of supply. More uncomfortable about after the first two years of controlling supply.  I'd be worrying about market manipulation or a MT Gox style dumping  Bitcoin on the market like last year. The risk of oversupply may be enough disensentive to prevent people holding onto Chia. So Chia won't allow pumping and dumping.  

I'm more comfortable with Chia Network short term control of supply. More uncomfortable about after the first two years of controlling supply.  I'd be worrying about market manipulation or a MT Gox style dumping  Bitcoin on the market like last year. The risk of oversupply may be enough disensentive to prevent people holding onto Chia. Now we expect chia coins to appreciate over time as markets adopt it, we just want that to be a bit smoother and a bit less extreme

And as to adoption, we are also going to be making sure that the major exchanges in the markets where chia payments are headed are liquid and ready to transform chia to a local currency if needed. It's not just the Global 5000 that we're targeting - it's the entire eco system of cryptocurrency providers

As a public company by the time the network is launched we can make certain pre commitments that can only be changed with disclosure on pain of violating securities laws. As such we can articulate what we generally will and wont do lending chia or adjusting interest rates. That you can read our plans on the SEC's website and watch the market means you have a lot more insight into what and how we will influence the supply of chia.

@hoffmang  what you said seems to me that Chia company will act like the federal reserve to regulate supply of Chia in the market to prevent unfavorable supply / demand imbalances. I get the value of it, but also see some issues. How can Chia users (or companies which loaned chia) trust this private entity will do its job truthfully and competently? What is the value proposition for the first major enterprises to borrow chia and use it before it has gained wider acceptance? What’s a specific use case that it will make their job easier than conventional means of doing business? In an unregulated cryptocurrency the incentive for the early adopters is usually that they will make a profit on the coins they are acquiring as an investment, not as a medium of exchange. Seems to me that chia isn’t planning on going with that formula. Curious to learn more.
The next two milestones you should be on the lookout for are our “green” paper on our Nakamoto style consensus algorithm and the upcoming proof of space optimization competition. Both real soon now.
We will launch when Chia is ready, and not a moment before. :-) Great progress is being made.

The company can lower the interest rates on offer to loan chia which puts more chia into the coin market. Second, the Company can dip into the Chia strategic reserve and offer it to buy our stock back with chia coins - again adding more coins to the supply and transfering the appreciation from the coin market to the Company's equity

edit.body: The promotional videos are amazing. What do you mean by payee identity? Would identity be mandatory? Nobody wants to link their identity to every purchase. For example if a woman bought some sexy underware, probably doesn't want purchase permanently on the block chain linked to a sexy underware retailer. Plus with the burglary and targeted thefts, it seems privacy for self protection is an issue. I probably have made far too many wrong presumptions here. I would like the option of linking my id to transactions if only I have access, for business reasons. e.g But I don't want my competitors knowing where I'm purchasing my raw materials from as it gives away my competitive edge. On the other hand ID would overcome the KYC problems and allow users to use Chia to proove that they are a KYC registered user, without having to provide your ID to dubious 3rd partys (such as Coinbase use of nafarious 3rd party's).

It's what makes bitcoin so dominant, it's been banged on for longest and by the best, and so far it's held up the best.

@wouterarkink Our immediate practical issue with inflation is that if it goes to zero then that's a massive security problem. In the other direction if transaction fees get too high then that can be fixed via a soft fork where something like 10% of a transaction fee goes to the farmer who processed it and the rest goes into a pool which is spread out over time effectively acting like a block reward. Doing that well requires knowledge of some empirical information about how the system is working though and is best put off into the future where it can be implemented well if and when it's ever needed.

edit.body: To add to the inflation discussion. Deflation is a risk in the current debt based monetary system. If the money supply decreases (deflation), the value of money generally increases. This would lead to difficulty in paying future debt, since the debt burden increases. That's why in the CURRENT monetary system inflation is important. If money would not be debt based (money comes into circulation by people taking loans), a stable money supply would not be a problem. As society gets more productive and produce more stuff with the same means, the value of a stable currency would go up, distributing the benefits of a more productive society to everyone.

@pulledpork First, as you noted, when Bram has mentioned the "generator" (2, 1, (1 - D)/8), he isn't referring to a generator of the class group (i.e. the order of that particular element could be lower than the order of the class group). Anyway, while class group elements are generators of cyclic subgroups of the class group, it's taken to be a computationally hard problem to find elements of low order. text.body: And this results in the following coin supply/reward schedule (plotted against bitcoin): https://imgur.com/a/De0G2

edit.body:
That may be true but it's also pretty easy to have a smooth emission curve and I'm not sure what exactly the benefits are of using a bitcoin-like halving schedule. Monero does the following: Block Reward Schedule:
Let denote M = 2^64-1 (a constant), and
Let denote A = the current Monero Money Supply in atomar units (in "monoshis", 1 XMR = 10^12 "monoshis") (i.e. 10^12 times the current total money supply in XMR)
Then the nominal block reward (BR_nom) for the next block (for a target block time of 2 minutes) is given by
BR_nom = max( 0.6, floor( (M - A) / 2^19 ) / 10^12 )
Note that M and A are uint64 numbers, and so is "M-A". The "floor( (...)/ 2^19)" operation shifts this integer number 19 bits to the right, such that the integer is now small enough to be expressed by the mantissa (52 bits) of a standard 64-bit "double" data type without any loss. Hence the operation "(...)/10^12" can be carried out with fractional "double" data types, as XMR moneros units are usually represented (with 12 fractional decimal digits).

I think that is also a mistake at this point in time as we can see the issues that the Euro is having trying to deal with vastly different economies like Germany, Greece and Spain with smaller economies suffering from an inability to be able to take any monetary action (due to a unified currency).

I do think that we have a lot of historical data about the various currencies around the world and their inflation/supply scheduling and how they play out on a global scale, so it's not like this '1st release' that you refer to is just a guess. It could be based on publicly available historical data. It probably wouldn't play out perfectly but it could be approximated to a greater extent than you might be giving credit, in my opinion

I also agree with this quote and have noticed that the crypto community tends to focus on interesting technical problems and scaling but spends much less time focused on the very important distribution and supply issues, so it's great that it's being discussed here

>Anyways I think this is a more complex subject than Bitcoiners/Cryptocurrency enthuasists often realize and just trying to bake in a currency inflation into the 1st release of code that will work well through history is too idealistic and impractical.

@jonspock I think that your response makes some very well articulated points.  It's fair to draw a link between our current monetary policy and the hyperconsumerism/overconsumption that we see happening.  While I think that the deflationary/low consumption model benefits the world from a resource persepective, I worry about the plight of the hundreds of millions/billions of poor people that are just starting to move out of poverty under our currenty system.
This more global standpoint is not so relevant now, but will become relevant if it becomes an mainstream currency

Inflation within a global economic standpoint is ideal as it doesn't incentivise users to sit on the currency, as it will be worth more later. It encourages the use of the coin as a mode of money as it loses a smidgen of value each year.

edit.body: @jonspock without an agreed level of inflation what's to stop a Chia developer creating a fork with varying levels of inflation later. This is still possible. Yet having a set figure of inflation, set pre release gives stakeholders some trust in the long term future of the currency. The inflation is such that there is still a reward to farm even in 100 years time, compared to if there was a set value of coins to be minted without inflation. This deflationary scenario would limit incentive for farmers once all Chia coins had been farmed. Inflation keeps the wheels turning and adds an incentised lubricant for farming, even when the majority of Chia has been farmed

@cyptogeek that's often stated as an issue with deflation but do you know of any actual examples in history?  I think an 'ideal' amount is also a guess and the current statistics are gamed to make it look like the inflation rate (in terms of prices) is much lower than reality. In terms of deflation discouraging spending, people will always buy what the need and if they are discouraged buying useless stuff it's not that bad because that was essentially wasteful production anyways.  With our current monetary systems inflation is needed to keep it going and that is why deflation is painted so badly by the economists since it's likely to result in a complete collapse. We had some slight deflation in 2008 once home prices stopped inflating and there was utter panic about the system with threats made to representatives about martial law if they didn't vote for the banking bailouts (as far as I know).  Anyways I think this is a more complex subject than Bitcoiners/Cryptocurrency enthuasists often realize and just trying to bake in a currency inflation into the 1st release of code that will work well through history is too idealistic and impractical.
It's also complex because there's not a direct correlation between money supply and price inflation, though it's widely agreed that the two are linked

@cyptogeek you're right about issues with deflation but the situation is quite complex in crypto since Chia aims to be a L1 solution with lots of scaling happening on L2, which could potentially have different economic factors
@akashnil great response - you're totally right that cryptocurrencies seem like a hybrid of currency and asset and it's hard to tell right now where the balance lies (X% currency, 100-X% asset)
If you have Bitcoin are you likely to use it as currency now? For many reasons including deflation, possibly not. Chia is aiming to be currency.
low inflation can lead to economic stagnation and periods of high unemployment. This is because deflationcan discourage spending because things will be cheaper in the future.
3% inflation seems to be the amount many economists settle on as being ideal. If Chia becomes mainstream money you want to incourage spending.

That's because people put some trust into the future of the currency they are investing in. For present day investors, 'deflationary' attribute of bitcoin is actually a plus. If that assumption is changed, it subtly breaks the expectations of current owners. I think a coin should be deflationary if it is a form of asset, and it should be inflationary if it is a medium of exchange (currency). It's never purely one or the other, but a combination. An asset becomes a currency depending on how liquid it is (cost of transaction / scaling issues etc.). I don't think a coin can be purely an asset, because it doesn't have an intrinsic value. I think one way to get intrinsic value of a coin as an asset should be proportional to how good it is to transact with it. Unfortunately that also depends on perceived value of it as an asset, the stability of its value relative to other things etc. So it is a complex question to answer, what should be the right amount of inflation for a coin to be successful?
I think that this highlights the importance of getting these ‘right’ from day 0, since it will be hard to change these after launch

Also just to add one more thought to this topic: the crypto community seems to be reticent but willing to fork for technical reasons (e.g. segwit, changing max block size) but seems concretely against changing the economic assumptions built into the protocol. If anyone mentions wanting to change the max number of bitcoins to any number above 21 million you’ll face significant pushback.

A quick recap of the situation from our side.  Our submission failed because we did not test the code on the bot in time.  Since the bot environment was different from the local testing environment, the code that worked when testing locally failed on the bot.  The bot was not added to the channel until the competition day, and so we did not have access to the bot until then.  After the bot was added, it took several more hours to develop a successful deployment script, and by then it was too late.  We didn't touch the algorithm we used, which is the core of the challenge.

We thank the competition team for their assistance.

There's a general approach which is fundamentally different with Chiascript than with Solidity. Chiascript is intended to support 'smart transactions' meaning everybody makes tiny little scripts which govern their own funds but there isn't a giant monolithic 'smart contract' which looks like a real program. TBH, I think we agree about DAGs. I just think you're missing potential solutions.
The subject of orphans in a DAG is complicated and nasty. There are a lot of incentives to freeze out other miners
For latency and scaling you need net settlement, basically meaning Lightning
Also, orphans only happen when the DAG is... sharded.

That's the biggest source of latency to exist, anywhere. Even if you set 30 second blocks, and I think BTC Core can only do 20 without a ton of orphans/desyncing, that's still 30 seconds that are needed if you find a secure DAG.
You still need some kind of ordering and reconciliation and they're basically a disaster
What I like about DAGs is simply the lack of batching.

As for sharding and DAGs I'm very familiar with them and have studied them extensively and come to the conclusion that they're just plain bad ideas. Sharding gets a small scaling benefit for permanent and nasty compromises to complexity and security. DAGs get a small to imaginary improvement in latency and orphan rate with similar tradeoffs. For Chia we're doing to doing something which is... sort of comparable to DAGs, but that's the subject of a rather technical write-up we haven't published yet which will be about the closest thing to a 'white paper' you'll see from us
Which is why I've stuck around :P I think if Chia continues with the BTC architecture, it'll be the best coin in existence with said architecture. ;)

From the 2019 paper, (m of n), "We implement our scheme and evaluate it among groups of up to 256 of co-located and 128 geographically-distributed parties, and among small groups of embedded devices. We find that in the LAN setting, our scheme outperforms all prior works by orders of magnitude, and that it is efficient enough for use even on smartphones or hardware tokens. @soret - people are complex and interested in cryptocurrencies for many different reasons.  Your personal reasons may be valid, but there's an equally valid group of people that are interested in moving money around faster and more efficiently than the modern banking system.  Other people are interested in offering digital banking services to the 2 billion+ un-banked and underbanked people, over half of whom have a basic android phone that could support a mobile wallet. There's also an argument to be made that opt-in financial systems are much more democratic and it is a great improvement over the current system to choose which currency you want to transact in based on the rules of that system. I think that being too narrow minded about the benefits and purposes of crypto isn't a good idea but instead it should be a diverse coalition of interested people from around the world.

Why I still have confidence Chia will succeed despite SEC:

Premine will fund future development (Cash flow For existing investors & for further development).

 I believe a larger premine would be required, with a promise of selling X amounts in set periods of days or weeks to prevent the fear equivalent to the Mt Gox sell off recently that was linked to erratic price of BTC over this period. It would also allow for a calmer long term currency price. EOS ICO worked as a calmer and more decentralised sell off giving anyone the ability to be part of the eco system (I don't like EOS!). Having a frequent and reliable sell off, to encourage more adoption, and would not negate price as speculators would not be worrying about a big Chia sell off FUD crashing the price of their investment.

A more regular, decentralised and predictable sell off of Chia holdings would justify a higher premine as the concerns about centralisation from such a large premine would be quashed with a promise of relinquished holdings over a set period of years.

Why I still have confidence Chia will succeed despite SEC:

Premine will fund future development (Cash flow For existing investors & for further development).

 I believe a larger premine would be required, with a promise of selling X amounts in set periods to prevent the fear equivalent to the Mt Gox sell off recently that was linked to stunted price of BTC over this period. It would also allow for a calmer long term currency price. EOS ICO worked as a calmer and more decentralised sell off. Having a frequent and reliable sell off, to encourage more holders would gain more adoption, and would increase price as speculators would not be worrying about a big Chia selloff (I predict frequent Click bait FUD "Chia sell off" )

A more regular, decentralised and predictable sell off of Chia holdings would justify a higher premine as the concerns about centralisation from such a large premine would be quashed with a promise of relinquished holdings over a set period of years.

I'm tempted to elaborate, but before I do that I want apologize for the off-topic for those who aren't interested in UBI,  I'll  close my digression with this single, longish statement.

The idea that came to me started exactly from the reflection that cryptocurrencies have similar or more inequal distribution compared to general populations wealth. I noticed potential fix, which can be baked into the contract, i.e. if you introduce explicit exponential token 'corruption', i.e. from every token deposited to an addreess one could spend less and less over time. Tokens half-life could be set to a custom value, a year, 5, 10, whatever. Of course without continuous inflow of fresh tokens that wouldn't make sense, and that's where the UBI idea comes in. If you add an idea of 'verified' personal addresses, they could produce implicit (no on-chain records required), linear inflow of fresh tokens. In the end instead of fixed hard limit (like 21M bitcoins) you end up with this nice, dynamic equilibrium of linear inflow of UBI and exp. corruption that converges naturally.

It would be strange if noone came up with this idea before - which after a moment of googling lead me to GoodDollar, which happened to be announced... the day before :D

The benefits are clear - trully global, uncontrolled, uniform, enforced across countries UBI model. Managing it would be challenging, but hopefully not impossible. Number of main problems that come to your mind immediately are:
1. Verified personal addresses - very hard, but probably doable, incentive for cheating is limitted, as the inflow is steady. Requires cooperation with other identity verfiers like banks or governments.
2. Tuning - currencies appreciation would be left totally to the markets, meaning it could become impractical and insufficient source of income. Protocol could allow for tuning within fixed constraints (like the expected number of tokens to which the system converges should be unchangeable).
3. Scaling - since the tokens get corrupted over time, hodling isn't that appealing and users are incentivised to spend it sooner rather than later. That's good for the market, but requires a lot of on chain capacity (or some smart off chain solutions)
4. Global cost - running anything like that on global scale would require a great resiliency. PoW is clearly to wasteful and doesn't fit the idea.

With that last reflection, half jokingly I dropped yesterdays message. My post obiously wasn't serious, or even really a suggestion. There's no doubt, Chia team will be busy developing the currency for next few years. But long term, if you really wanted to change the world :heart_eyes: you could consider running Chia and it's UBI variant side by side (maybe on compatible protocols) one as a store of value, industrial/banking solution the other meant as a source for everydays currency.

Chia's distributed farming will avoid making a handful of miners rich in exchange for burning electricity doing nothing, but it won't help people below the poverty line become wealthy.

If you want to read up more on changing large scale issues like inequality, I highly recommend doing some reading about systems theory and theories of systems change - there’s a lot of interesting work being done in this area and it seems like something that you might be interested in based on your previous comments
@winget You're spot on. You just reminded me of the main principle of farming, that it won't be worthwhile purchasing hdd's to farm as it will not break even.

Cryptocurrencies are just tools for moving money around more efficiently (hopefully) and democratically than the current financial system. Like Bram said in his previous post, they don’t have the ability to solve income inequality directly

@cyptogeek  My understanding of Chia is that farming rewards are planned to be somewhat low in token amount, but even if that’s not the case then it still won’t bring wealth to many.  If farming rewards are high in $ equivalent (enough to justify buying hard drives to farm), wealthy people will be the ones with enough resources to actually buy hundreds of terabytes of HDDs.

@bramcohen I think the world needs someone like you to make economies work. Will Chia Network create something to resolve economic issues, possibly in the future, considering cryptocurrencies won't do this themselves? (I was quietly hoping that the decentralised nature of farming would bring wealth to the many 🤔)

Also there's a misconception that people getting rich off cryptocurrencies can help with inequality. That's just not true. When there's massive random wealth redistribution it can result in *some* poor people becoming rich, but the overall effect is a greater gini coefficient, which means greater wealth inequality.

But this is somewhat off topic. Cryptocurrencies do not in and of themselves help nor hurt things like income inequality, except to the extent that they might someday cut back on finance industry inefficiency (although so far they haven't helped with that much at all, in fact finance and finance-like types have made and are making lots of money off cryptocurrency market inefficiency and manipulation)

@techaspirer UBI can look many different ways if you play with the numbers. If you set it to just barely over the poverty line and made there only be a single income tax bracket at 35% and got rid of a lot of welfare programs it would look a lot like things do today but with a lot less cost, bullshit and weird disincentives
@bramcohen I'd be interested to hear sometime why you like UBI over generic welfare (prove issue (disability, laid off, significant other left), get money).

gooddollar sounds like a scam, and its association with UBI is just feel good bullshit to help sell it. And I say that as someone who generally likes the idea of UBI. Cryptocurrencies and social welfare programs are two unrelated subjects.

UBI gives people who don't need money, can help people who need extra money, and enables people who are poor by choice. I understand UBI isn't equivalent to a job. They still get to do less because of UBI though.

Crypto UBI is also super maniputable and there's no reason for investors to buy it.

Eh. Anyways. I don't feel like anyone should get paid for existing. I think people should get money when they need it because the situation screws them, not when they themselves screw them. I also think we need to make jobs available.
